source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: About 400 pressure-tubes made of cold-worked $\mathsf { Z r } { \mathsf { - } } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ are used in a CANDU power reactor to contain the nuclear fuel and the heat transport fluid, heavy water, at between 250 to $3 1 0 \mathrm { { } \mathrm { { c } } }$ at a pressure of about $1 0 \ \mathrm { { M P a } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: About 400 pressure-tubes made of cold-worked $\mathsf { Z r } { \mathsf { - } } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ are used in a CANDU power reactor to contain the nuclear fuel and the heat transport fluid, heavy water, at between 250 to $3 1 0 \mathrm { { } \mathrm { { c } } }$ at a pressure of about $1 0 \ \mathrm { { M P a } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The in-core, primary coolant containment of CANDU nuclear reactors are tubes, $6 . 3 \textrm { m }$ long with an inside diameter of $1 0 3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and a wall thickness of $4 . 2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ , made from coldworked $\mathsf { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ alloy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The in-core, primary coolant containment of CANDU nuclear reactors are tubes, $6 . 3 \textrm { m }$ long with an inside diameter of $1 0 3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and a wall thickness of $4 . 2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ , made from coldworked $\mathsf { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ alloy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The in-core, primary coolant containment of CANDU nuclear reactors are tubes, $6 . 3 \textrm { m }$ long with an inside diameter of $1 0 3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ and a wall thickness of $4 . 2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ , made from coldworked $\mathsf { Z r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ alloy.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The pressure tubes contain $\mathrm { U O } _ { 2 }$ -fuel and heat transport $\mathrm { D } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O }$ at a pressure of about $1 0 \mathbf { M P a }$ and at a temperature ranging from 250 to $2 6 5 \mathrm { { ^ \circ C } }$ at the inlet ends to 290 to $3 1 5 \mathrm { ^ \circ C }$ at the outlet ends.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The pressure tubes contain $\mathrm { U O } _ { 2 }$ -fuel and heat transport $\mathrm { D } _ { 2 } \mathrm { O }$ at a pressure of about $1 0 \mathbf { M P a }$ and at a temperature ranging from 250 to $2 6 5 \mathrm { { ^ \circ C } }$ at the inlet ends to 290 to $3 1 5 \mathrm { ^ \circ C }$ at the outlet ends.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The profile of the neutron flux is a flattened cosine along the tube with a maximum value of $3 . 7 \times 1 0 ^ { 1 7 } \mathrm { ~ n } / ( \mathrm { s } { \cdot } \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 } )$ $( E > 1 ~ \mathrm { M e V } _ { , }$ at the center.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: Test materials were taken from pressure tubes removed from CANDU reactors after up to about 15 years of service, with fluences up to $9 \ \times \ 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \ \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ $E > 1$ MeV).3

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The tubes are produced by extrusion at about $8 1 5 \mathrm { { ‰} }$ , followed by a final $2 5 \%$ cold-draw

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The tubes are produced by extrusion at about $8 1 5 \mathrm { { ‰} }$ , followed by a final $2 5 \%$ cold-draw

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The $\alpha$ -phase grains are shaped like elongated platelets (containing about 1 at $\%$ Nb in solution) with an aspect ratio of about 1:5:50 in the radial, transverse, and longitudinal directions of the tube, respectively.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The $\alpha$ -phase grains are shaped like elongated platelets (containing about 1 at $\%$ Nb in solution) with an aspect ratio of about 1:5:50 in the radial, transverse, and longitudinal directions of the tube, respectively.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk1
evidence_span: The $\pmb { \alpha }$ -grain diameter in the radial direction varies from about 0.3 to $0 . 5 ~ { \mu \mathrm { m } }$ at the back and front ends of the extrusion, respectively.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: straight specimens were produced by first grinding or milling the pressure tube blank into a flat, $2 \mathrm { - } \mathrm { m m }$ -thick plate. The specimens were then spark-machined from the plate to final dimensions of $4 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ in width and $2 \ \mathrm { m m }$ in thickness, with a gage length of $1 0 ~ \mathrm { m m }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The tensile tests were performed in air in a furnace at a strain rate of about $1 \times 1 0 ^ { \cdot } \ \mathrm { { ^ { 3 } } }$ per second until the specimen failed.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: A procedure was developed using 17- mm curved C(T) specimens [3].

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The specimens were spark-eroded from pressure tubes and then fatigue-precracked for about $2 \mathrm { m m }$ at room temperature such that the final $a / W$ value was about 0.5, where a was the crack length and $W$ the width of the specimen.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The fracture tests were performed in air in a furnace using a constant displacement rate of $0 . 2 5 \mathrm { { m m } / \mathrm { { m i n } } }$ . This is approximately equal to an initial stress intensity factor rate of $0 . 3 ~ \mathrm { M P a } \mathrm { \sqrt { m } / s }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: This is approximately equal to an initial stress intensity factor rate of $0 . 3 ~ \mathrm { M P a } \mathrm { \sqrt { m } / s }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The tests continued until the PD indicated that the crack had propagated for about 3 to $4 \ \mathrm { m m }$ or until the specimen fractured.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: Burst tests were performed on $4 6 0 – \mathrm { m m }$ lengths cut from pressure tubes.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: A throughwall slot $0 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ wide was spark-machined in the midsection of the tube

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: KRAK-GAGEs4 with a $3 0 \mathrm { - m m }$ gage length were mounted at each end of the slot.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: Strain gages to measure axial and circumferential strains were attached to the tube $5 0 ~ \mathrm { { m m } }$ ahead of and in line with the crack.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: A $2 . 5 { \cdot } \mathbf { m m } .$ . thick plastic liner was placed inside the tube

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: steel bell jar that provided protection from blast and the ability to heat the test section to $3 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The pressure was cycled at room temperature to fatigue-sharpen the crack, extending the notch about $5 \ \mathrm { m m }$ at each end.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: Post-failure analysis had shown that potential drop usually was accurate to $0 . 1 \ \mathrm { m m }$ .

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The test section was pressurized with water using a pump driven by compressed air.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk2
evidence_span: The cost of a Charpy test is about one tenth that of a $C ( \mathsf { T } )$ test.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Curved Charpy specimens were cut from the pressure tubes in such a way that the crack propagated in the axial direction (Fig. 1).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The tests were performed between room temperature and $3 5 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ using an instrumented impact tester.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The microstructure was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and thin film electron microscopy (TEM)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The microstructure was examined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and thin film electron microscopy (TEM)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: a preliminary study showed that this introduced a damage layer approximately $0 . 0 3 ~ \mathrm { { m m } }$ thick below the surface.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: For XRD analysis, samples about $1 \mathrm { c m } ^ { 2 }$ by $0 . 4 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ thick were cut initially

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: For TEM analysis, disks $3 ~ \mathrm { m m }$ in diameter were punched out of slices that had been thinned to about $0 . 1 \mathrm { { \ m m } }$ in thickness

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The TEM analysis was performed at 100 and $3 0 0 ~ \mathrm { { k V } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Microchemical information was obtained by energy dispersive $\mathbf { X }$ -ray (EDX) analysis with a spatial resolution of about 5 nm.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Irradiated $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ pressure tube material has a low work-hardening capability.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Type B behavior was observed only on specimens tested above $2 0 0 \mathrm { { ^ \circ C } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: Type B behavior became more frequent with increasing test temperature, and above $2 7 0 \mathrm { { ^circ C } }$ most of the tests had Type B load-displacement curves.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: All unirradiated materials tested from room temperature to $3 0 0 \mathrm { ‰}$ exhibited Type A behavior.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The tensile properties approach asymptotic values at fluences above $1 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 }$ $\mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: All irradiated $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ pressure tube material tested thus far had about $3 \mathrm { \ m m }$ of crack extension without fracturing abruptly, except in isolated cases at temperatures below $7 0 \mathrm { { ^ \circ C } }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: The $J _ { R }$ curves for material that had been irradiated to less than $4 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \ \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ had a decreasing slope

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk3
evidence_span: When the fluence was higher than $4 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \ \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$ , most of the $J _ { R }$ curves had three stages

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: J_R curves of two irradiated Zr-2.5Nb specimens tested at 280°C Specimen P4F17 had a fluence of 1.2×10^25 n/m² (E>1 MeV), and Specimen P3J09 had a fluence of 7×10^25 n/m² (E>1 MeV)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: J_R curves of two irradiated Zr-2.5Nb specimens tested at 280°C Specimen P4F17 had a fluence of 1.2×10^25 n/m² (E>1 MeV), and Specimen P3J09 had a fluence of 7×10^25 n/m² (E>1 MeV)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Note that Specimen P3J09 has the three-stage behavior and Specimen P4F17 does not.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Note that Specimen P3J09 has the three-stage behavior and Specimen P4F17 does not.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Typically, there is 3 mm of stable crack growth at room temperature and 7 mm at 300°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Typically, there is 3 mm of stable crack growth at room temperature and 7 mm at 300°C

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: J_R curve from a burst test at room temperature of a Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube irradiated to 8×10^25 n/m² (E>1 MeV)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Fracture toughness decreases with increasing neutron fluence

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: The fracture toughness in terms of dJ/da decreased rapidly in the first four years of service. The decrease in fracture toughness slowed down considerably after the fluence reached about 3×10^25 n/m²

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Similar large scatter in fracture toughness, with a range of about 100 MPa in dJ/da, was also observed in unirradiated material

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: J_i increases linearly with dJ/da

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: the fracture toughness of irradiated Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube material increases with increasing test temperature

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: There is an apparent transition temperature ranging between 70 and 150°C, depending on the tube

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Up to about 15 years of operation, the hydrogen concentrations in the Zr-2.5Nb pressure tubes are low (≈0.2 at% at tube center)

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: Data from the P3L09 outlet showed that in material with about 0.6 at.% circumferential deuterides the dJ/da at temperatures below 120°C is lower than in the material with 0.1 at% deuterium

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: at temperatures between 240 and 300°C, hydrogen concentration had little effect on fracture toughness; the specimens with higher hydrogen concentration even appeared to have slightly higher toughness

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk4
evidence_span: at temperatures between 240 and 300°C, hydrogen concentration had little effect on fracture toughness; the specimens with higher hydrogen concentration even appeared to have slightly higher toughness

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: During the hot extrusion of the pressure tubes, the front end of the pressure tubes is worked at a higher temperature than the back end; as a result, the pressure tubes show an increasing strength from the front to the back end.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The tubes can be installed in a reactor with either end at the inlet of the fuel channel. Thus the initial mechanical properties of the inlet and outlet ends were different when the tubes were installed in the reactor.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: However, there is no clear indication that initial tensile strength affects post-irradiation fracture toughness.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: As fracture toughness is a function of test temperature and fluence, only data from tests in the upper shelf region, 240 to 300°C, were plotted as a function of fluence for material near the inlets and outlets (Fig. 11).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: As fracture toughness is a function of test temperature and fluence, only data from tests in the upper shelf region, 240 to 300°C, were plotted as a function of fluence for material near the inlets and outlets (Fig. 11).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: Figure 11a depicts the fracture toughness of materials from the outlet ends, showing that the data from the front ends are not significantly different from those from the back ends of the tubes.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: Figure 11b indicates that the same holds true for the inlet ends of the tubes.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: In spite of significant toughness variations, these data indicated that post-irradiation toughness was independent of initial mechanical strength.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: Figures 11a and 11b also indicate that the 50°C difference in irradiation temperature at inlet and outlet does not significantly influence the fracture toughness.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The producers of the pressure tubes measured the longitudinal tensile properties at the front-end of each pressure tube at 300°C.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: These properties include the 0.2% YS, UTS, and total elongation.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: These properties include the 0.2% YS, UTS, and total elongation.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: These properties include the 0.2% YS, UTS, and total elongation.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: Figure 12 shows no correlation between dJ/da and 0.2% YS, UTS, and elongation.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: Note that the very tough tube, B2P12, has initial longitudinal tensile properties in the middle of the range.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: The total CVN energy as a function of temperature for two irradiated materials is shown in Fig. 13.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: These curves have similar temperature dependencies to dJ/da, although the exact transition temperature is higher for CVN energy than for dJ/da (see Fig. 9).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: Dimples were found on material tested at all temperatures, indicating that void growth and coalescence had taken place.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk5
evidence_span: A comparison of Figs. 14a and 14b shows that the density and length of these fissures decreased with increasing toughness, although a quantitative evaluation still needs to be performed.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: Nb-rich precipitates form in the $\pmb { \alpha }$ -phase (and at sub-grain boundaries and $\alpha / \beta$ interfaces) and are also visible in Fig. 17.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: Fe is also depleted from the $\beta$ -phase and dispersed throughout the material.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The precipitation of Nb from supersaturated solid solution in the $\alpha$-phase and the redistribution of Fe from the $\beta$-phase are both fluence-dependent

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: Lattice parameter measurements obtained by XRD indicate that there is an expansion of the $\alpha$-phase lattice that reaches a saturation value after fluences of about $1 { \cdot } 2 \times 1 0 ^ { 2 5 } \ \mathrm { n } / \mathrm { m } ^ { 2 }$

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: Similar measurements have been used to plot the degree of decomposition of the $\beta$-phase.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: XRD analysis shows, however, that enrichment of the $\beta$-phase by $\mathtt { N b }$ occurs during service and increases significantly from the inlet towards the outlet (Fig. 18).

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The enrichment is the result of a gradual decomposition of metastable 2040 at. $\%$ Nb enriched $\beta \not { q } { \ Z } { \tau }$ towards a stable 85 at. $\%$ Nb $\beta$ Nb product.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The enrichment is the result of a gradual decomposition of metastable 2040 at. $\%$ Nb enriched $\beta \not { q } { \ Z } { \tau }$ towards a stable 85 at. $\%$ Nb $\beta$ Nb product.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: An $\boldsymbol { \omega }$ -phase, present after fabrication of the pressure tube (produced during a final heat-treatment of $4 0 0 \mathrm { ‰}$ for $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ ), remains after service in all cases.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: specimens. (a) Low-toughness tube P3F13, specimen $C 2$ , tested at $2 4 0 ^ { \circ } C$ (b) High-toughness tube B2P12, specimen C2, tested at $\bar { 3 } 0 0 ^ { \circ } C$ .

evidence_span: The decomposition of the $\alpha \cdot$ and $\beta$ -phases during service in CANDU reactors operating at about $2 5 0 { - } 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ is distinct from the changes observed by thermal treatments (10 to 50 days at about $5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ to form the equilibrium structure.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The decomposition of the $\alpha \cdot$ and $\beta$ -phases during service in CANDU reactors operating at about $2 5 0 { - } 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ is distinct from the changes observed by thermal treatments (10 to 50 days at about $5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ to form the equilibrium structure.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The decomposition of the $\alpha \cdot$ and $\beta$ -phases during service in CANDU reactors operating at about $2 5 0 { - } 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ is distinct from the changes observed by thermal treatments (10 to 50 days at about $5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ to form the equilibrium structure.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk6
evidence_span: The decomposition of the $\alpha \cdot$ and $\beta$ -phases during service in CANDU reactors operating at about $2 5 0 { - } 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ is distinct from the changes observed by thermal treatments (10 to 50 days at about $5 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ to form the equilibrium structure.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: compact specimens produce conservative $J _ { R }$ curves, i.e., the measured $J$ -integral is smaller than those obtained fro center cracked panels (CCP) [19], unless the materials are very brittle

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: The burst test, which is similar in deformation mode to the CCP, always produces higher $J _ { R }$ curves than the $\dot { 1 } \dot { 7 } - \mathrm { m m }$ curved C(T) specimens

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: Data from unirradiated $\mathbf { Z r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ materials also show that the measured toughness is size-dependent, with larger C(T) specimens giving higher dJ/da values [10]

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk7
evidence_span: For irradiated $\mathbf { Z r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ materials, $J _ { \varkappa }$ was unable to unify the two $J _ { R }$ curves produced by burst tests and curved C(T) specimens (Fig. 6)

evidence_span: There is a good qualitative correlation between the increase in dislocation density resulting from a-type loop formation and the decrease in fracture toughness.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk8

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: The Nb-rich precipitates contribute to the reduction in fracture toughness because, when the dislocation loops are completely removed by heating, the strength of the Zr-2.5Nb can be reduced to pre-irradiated values but the fracture toughness is still 25 to 50% lower than values for unirradiated material [8].

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: The β-phase does not dominate fracture behavior because the decomposition of the β- phase is position-dependent along the fuel channel (Fig. 18), whereas the fracture properties do not vary along the channel.

evidence_span: The fracture toughness of irradiated Zr-2.5Nb pressure tube decreases with fluence.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk8

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_019_chunk8
evidence_span: The post-irradiation fracture toughness was not affected by the initial tensile strength of the material.

evidence_span: The fracture toughness beyond the J-control region, as measured by 17-mm curved C(T) specimens, was conservative when compared with the burst test, because of the different constraint of the test pieces.
